title: Missing Critical Security Headers
description: The web terminal application does not implement standard security HTTP response headers. Analysis of HTTP responses shows absence of multiple critical security headers: (1) Content-Security-Policy (CSP) - no protection against XSS or inline script injection, (2) X-Frame-Options - no clickjacking protection, (3) X-Content-Type-Options - no MIME-sniffing protection, (4) Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS) - no HTTPS enforcement, (5) X-XSS-Protection - deprecated XSS protection disabled, (6) Referrer-Policy - no referrer control, (7) Permissions-Policy - no feature control. The HTTP response only includes basic headers: Accept-Ranges, Content-Length, Content-Type, and Date.
impact: Attackers can: (1) Exploit XSS vulnerabilities more easily without CSP protection, (2) Clickjack the application into an iframe for malicious purposes without X-Frame-Options protection, (3) Force browsers to sniff MIME types and execute content as scripts without X-Content-Type-Options, (4) Redirect users from HTTPS to HTTP enabling man-in-the-middle attacks without HSTS, (5) Use the application's features (microphone, camera, location) without restriction due to missing Permissions-Policy, (6) Leak sensitive information through referrer headers without Referrer-Policy control.
evidence:
POC execution confirmed all 7 security headers are missing. HTTP response headers returned: Accept-Ranges, Content-Length, Content-Type, Date. Security headers validation output:
[✗] Content-Security-Policy: MISSING
[✗] X-Frame-Options: MISSING
[✗] X-Content-Type-Options: MISSING
[✗] Strict-Transport-Security: MISSING
[✗] X-XSS-Protection: MISSING
[✗] Referrer-Policy: MISSING
[✗] Permissions-Policy: MISSING

VULNERABILITY CONFIRMED: 7 critical security headers are missing!
remediation: Implement all standard security headers in HTTP responses: (1) Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline' (if needed); style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline', (2) X-Frame-Options: DENY, (3) X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff, (4) Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains (when using HTTPS), (5) X-XSS-Protection: 0 (disable as CSP is primary defense), (6) Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin, (7) Permissions-Policy: camera=(), microphone=(), geolocation=(). These headers should be configured in the web server or application framework middleware to apply to all HTTP responses.
references: OWASP A01:2021 - Broken Access Control, CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure, CWE-95: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code, OWASP Secure Headers Project, MDN Web Docs - HTTP Headers
toolCallDescription: Document finding for missing critical security headers with verified POC
